content.text: Any number of the form a + bi where a, b in R and i = sqrt(-1), is called a complex number.

Notice that:
- All real numbers can be written as complex numbers by simply choosing b = 0.
- In the special case a = 0, we have a number of the form bi, b in R. We say this number is purely imaginary.

content.title: Real and Imaginary Parts
content.text:
If z = a + bi where a, b in R, then:
- a is the real part of z, written Re(z)
- b is the imaginary part of z, written Im(z)

For example:
- If z = 2 + 3i, then Re(z) = 2 and Im(z) = 3.
- If z = -sqrt(2)i, then Re(z) = 0 and Im(z) = -sqrt(2).

content.title: Complex Conjugates
content.text:
Suppose z = a + bi where a, b in R.
The complex conjugate of z is z* = a - bi.
Re(z*) = Re(z) and Im(z*) = -Im(z)
For example, if z = 2 + 3i then z* = 2 - 3i.

content.text: Operations with complex numbers are identical to those with radicals, but with i^2 = -1 rather than (sqrt(2))^2 = 2 or (sqrt(3))^2 = 3.

formulas.name: multiplication
formulas.formula: (a + bi)(c + di) = ac + adi + bci + bdi^2

content.title: Division
content.text:
When we perform division with radicals, we use the radical conjugate of the denominator to achieve a rational denominator.

For example, (1 + 2*sqrt(3))/(4 - sqrt(3)) = ((1 + 2*sqrt(3))/(4 - sqrt(3))) * ((4 + sqrt(3))/(4 + sqrt(3))) = (4 + sqrt(3) + 8*sqrt(3) + 6)/(16 - 3) = (10 + 9*sqrt(3))/13

In the previous Exercise we saw that multiplying a complex number by its complex conjugate also produces a real number. We can use this to achieve a real denominator.

For example, (1 + 2i)/(4 - i) = ((1 + 2i)/(4 - i)) * ((4 + i)/(4 + i)) = (4 + i + 8i + 2i^2)/(16 - i^2) = (2 + 9i)/17

content.name: division
content.formula: (a + bi)/(c + di) = ((a + bi)/(c + di)) * ((c - di)/(c - di)) = (ac - adi + bci - bdi^2)/(c^2 + d^2)

content.text:
Two complex numbers are equal when their real parts are equal and their imaginary parts are equal.

a + bi = c + di <=> a = c and b = d.

content.title: Proof by contradiction
content.text:
Suppose b != d. Now if a + bi = c + di where a, b, c, and d are real,
then bi - di = c - a
i(b - d) = c - a
i = (c - a)/(b - d) {as b != d}

This is false as the RHS is real but the LHS is imaginary.

Thus, the supposition is false. Hence b = d and furthermore a = c.

content.title: Find real numbers x and y such that:

problems.solution:
(x + 2i)(1 - i) = 5 + yi
x - xi + 2i + 2 = 5 + yi
(x + 2) + (2 - x)i = 5 + yi
Equating real and imaginary parts,
x + 2 = 5 and 2 - x = y
x = 3 and y = -1

content.title: Show that for all complex numbers z_1 and z_2:

problems.solution:
Let z_1 = a + bi and z_2 = c + di
z_1* = a - bi and z_2* = c - di
Now z_1 + z_2 = (a + c) + (b + d)i
(z_1 + z_2)* = (a + c) - (b + d)i
= a + c - bi - di
= a - bi + c - di
= z_1* + z_2*

Let z_1 = a + bi and z_2 = c + di
z_1*z_2 = (a + bi)(c + di)
= ac + adi + bci + bdi^2
= (ac - bd) + i(ad + bc)
(z_1*z_2)* = (ac - bd) - i(ad + bc) .... (1)
Also, z_1* * z_2*
= (a - bi)(c - di)
= ac - adi - bci + bdi^2
= (ac - bd) - i(ad + bc) .... (2)
From (1) and (2), (z_1*z_2)* = z_1* * z_2*

content.text: We can therefore plot any complex number on a plane as a unique ordered number pair. We refer to the plane as the complex plane or the Argand plane.

On the complex plane, the x-axis is called the real axis and the y-axis is called the imaginary axis.

- All real numbers with b = 0 lie on the real axis.
- All purely imaginary numbers with a = 0 lie on the imaginary axis.
- The origin (0, 0) lies on both axes. It corresponds to z = 0, a real number.
- Complex numbers that are neither real nor purely imaginary (a and b are both not 0) lie in one of the four quadrants.
The vector OP = (x, y) represents x + yi

For example:
- OP = (2, 3) represents 2 + 3i
- OQ = (4, -1) represents 4 - i
- OR = (0, -3) represents -3i
- OS = (-3, -1) represents -3 - i

content.title: Complex conjugate on the complex plane
content.text:
The complex conjugate of z = a + bi is z* = a - bi.
In the complex plane, z* is the reflection of z in the real axis.

content.text: The modulus of the complex number z = a + bi is the length of the vector (a, b), which is the real number |z| = sqrt(a^2 + b^2).

Notice that if z = a + bi then |z| gives the distance of the point (a, b) from the origin. This is consistent with the previous definition of modulus that |x| is the distance of real number x from the origin O.

For example, consider the complex number z = 3 + 2i.
The distance from O to P is its modulus, |z|.
|z| = sqrt(3^2 + 2^2) {Pythagoras}

content.title: Prove that |z_1*z_2| = |z_1||z_2| for all complex numbers z_1 and z_2
content.solution:
Let z_1 = a + bi and z_2 = c + di where a, b, c, and d are real.
z_1*z_2 = (a + bi)(c + di) = [ac - bd] + i[ad + bc]
Thus |z_1*z_2| = sqrt((ac - bd)^2 + (ad + bc)^2)
= sqrt(a^2c^2 - 2abcd + b^2d^2 + a^2d^2 + 2abcd + b^2c^2)
= sqrt(a^2(c^2 + d^2) + b^2(c^2 + d^2))
= sqrt((c^2 + d^2)(a^2 + b^2))
= sqrt(a^2 + b^2) * sqrt(c^2 + d^2)
= |z_1||z_2|

content.text:
Suppose the complex number z = a + bi is represented by the vector OP.

The argument of z, or simply arg z, is the angle theta, where -pi < theta <= pi is measured anticlockwise between the positive real axis and OP.

We specify the domain restriction -pi < theta <= pi to avoid confusion with the infinitely many possibilities for theta which are 2pi apart. This guarantees that z -> arg z = theta is a function.

Notice that:
- Real numbers (other than zero) have argument 0 or pi.
- Purely imaginary numbers have argument pi/2 or -pi/2.

content.title: Find |z| and arg z for z equal to:

problems.solution:
|z| = sqrt((-1)^2 + 3^2) = sqrt(10)
tan(phi) = 3/1 = 3, phi ≈ 1.25
But theta = pi - phi
arg z ≈ 1.89

|z| = sqrt((-3)^2 + (-1)^2) = sqrt(10)
tan(phi) = 1/3, phi ≈ 0.322
But theta = -pi + phi
arg z ≈ -2.82
